favoriteExamples.definition: said or shouted in order to tell someone that they are in danger:
favoriteExamples.original: Look out! There's a car coming!

favoriteExamples.definition: to decide or arrange to delay an event or activity until a later time or date:
favoriteExamples.original: I can't put off going to the dentist any longer.

favoriteExamples.definition: to hit someone with a vehicle and injure or kill them:
favoriteExamples.original: She was knocked down by a bus.

favoriteExamples.definition: to spend a lot of time in a place or with someone:
favoriteExamples.original: I've been hanging out backstage with the band.

favoriteExamples.definition: to return:
favoriteExamples.original: We can always go back to the original plan if necessary.

favoriteExamples.definition: to fill something with air:
favoriteExamples.original: Would you help me blow up these balloons?

favoriteExamples.definition: If a marriage breaks up or two people in a romantic relationship break up, their marriage or their relationship ends:
favoriteExamples.original: Jenny and George have broken up.

favoriteExamples.definition: said to encourage someone to do something, especially to hurry or try harder, or to tell you something:
favoriteExamples.original: Come on, Helen, you can tell me. I won't tell anyone.

favoriteExamples.definition: to start doing a particular job or activity:
favoriteExamples.original: Patti took up (= continued) the story where Sue had left off.

favoriteExamples.definition: to continue:
favoriteExamples.original: If you go on (= continue behaving) like this, you won't have any friends left at all.

favoriteExamples.definition: to give a piece of written work or a document to someone to read, judge, or deal with:
favoriteExamples.original: Have you given that essay in yet?

favoriteExamples.definition: to raise something, or to fix something in a raised position:
favoriteExamples.original: Why don't you put up your hood/umbrella?

favoriteExamples.definition: to leave a place without taking someone or something with you:
favoriteExamples.original: He was forced to leave the country, leaving behind his wife and children.

favoriteExamples.definition: to stop doing a regular activity or job:
favoriteExamples.original: He's given up driving since his illness.

favoriteExamples.definition: to be reduced in price, value, amount, quality, level, or size:
favoriteExamples.original: The swelling's gone down but there's still a lot of bruising.

favoriteExamples.definition: to raise something, or to fix something in a raised position:
favoriteExamples.original: I put my hand up to ask the teacher a question.

favoriteExamples.definition: to put an object that you are holding onto the floor or onto another surface, or to stop carrying someone:
favoriteExamples.original: I put my bags down while we spoke.

favoriteExamples.definition: to continue:
favoriteExamples.original: Please go on with what you're doing and don't let us interrupt you.

favoriteExamples.definition: If one thing goes with another, they suit each other or they look or taste good together:
favoriteExamples.original: This wine goes particularly well with seafood.

favoriteExamples.definition: to be given something again that you had before:
favoriteExamples.original: He went next door to get his ball back.

favoriteExamples.definition: to leave a closed vehicle, building, etc.:
favoriteExamples.original: I'll get out when you stop at the traffic lights.

favoriteExamples.definition: to formally establish a new company, organization, system, way of working, etc.:
favoriteExamples.original: A committee has been set up to organize social events for the students.

favoriteExamples.original: I'll have to go back for my umbrella.

favoriteExamples.definition: to decide or arrange to delay an event or activity until a later time or date:
favoriteExamples.original: I can't put off going to the dentist any longer.

favoriteExamples.definition: to exercise in order to improve the strength or appearance of your body:
favoriteExamples.original: Huw works out in the gym two or three times a week.

favoriteExamples.definition: to raise something, or to fix something in a raised position:

favoriteExamples.definition: to delay someone or something:

favoriteExamples.definition: to finish, use, or sell all of something, so that there is none left:

favoriteExamples.original: She's just broken up with her boyfriend.

favoriteExamples.definition: to be given something again that you had before:
favoriteExamples.original: He went next door to get his ball back.

favoriteExamples.definition: to increase the price or value of something:
favoriteExamples.original: I see they've put up the price of fuel again.

favoriteExamples.definition: If you hear from someone, you get a letter, email, or phone call from that person, or that person tells you something:
favoriteExamples.original: You'll be hearing from my solicitors (= they will write to you about my complaint).

favoriteExamples.definition: to end a phone conversation:
favoriteExamples.original: He started shouting so I hung up (on him).

favoriteExamples.definition: to not go onto an area, or to stop someone or something going onto an area:
favoriteExamples.original: There was a notice saying 'Keep off the grass'.

favoriteExamples.definition: to put an object that you are holding onto the floor or onto another surface, or to stop carrying someone:
favoriteExamples.original: I put my bags down while we spoke.

favoriteExamples.definition: to raise something, or to fix something in a raised position:
favoriteExamples.original: I put my hand up to ask the teacher a question.

favoriteExamples.definition: to arrive somewhere in order to join a group of people, especially late or unexpectedly:
favoriteExamples.original: We were expecting 30 people to come, but half of them never showed up.

favoriteExamples.definition: to be similar to, and make someone think of, something or someone else:
favoriteExamples.original: Your hair and eyes remind me of your mother.

favoriteExamples.definition: When schools and colleges, or the teachers and students who go to them break up, their classes stop and the holidays start:
favoriteExamples.original: We broke up for the holidays in June.

favoriteExamples.definition: to hit someone with a vehicle and injure or kill them:
favoriteExamples.original: She was knocked down by a bus.

favoriteExamples.definition: to formally establish a new company, organization, system, way of working, etc.:
favoriteExamples.original: A committee has been set up to organize social events for the students.

favoriteExamples.definition: to begin by doing something, or to make something begin by doing something:
favoriteExamples.original: I'd like to start off by thanking you all for coming today.

favoriteExamples.definition: to stop doing a regular activity or job:
favoriteExamples.original: We're going to give up our sports club membership after this year.

favoriteExamples.definition: to decide or arrange to delay an event or activity until a later time or date:
favoriteExamples.original: I can't put off going to the dentist any longer.

favoriteExamples.definition: to happen:
favoriteExamples.original: I'm sure we never hear about a lot of what goes on in government.

favoriteExamples.definition: to go to a place in order to collect someone:
favoriteExamples.original: I'll call for you at eight.

favoriteExamples.definition: If a flame blows out or you blow it out, it stops burning when a person or the wind blows on it:
favoriteExamples.original: The sudden breeze made the candles blow out.

favoriteExamples.definition: to continue doing something, or to cause something to continue:
favoriteExamples.original: Sorry to interrupt, please carry on (with what you were saying).

favoriteExamples.definition: to put an object that you are holding onto the floor or onto another surface, or to stop carrying someone:
favoriteExamples.original: I put my bags down while we spoke.

favoriteExamples.definition: to stop doing a regular activity or job:

favoriteExamples.definition: to do or complete something, especially that you have said you would do or that you have been told to do:
favoriteExamples.original: Our soldiers carried out a successful attack last night.

favoriteExamples.definition: If people or animals put weight on, they become heavier:
favoriteExamples.original: He's put on ten pounds in the last month.

favoriteExamples.definition: said to encourage someone to do something, especially to hurry or try harder, or to tell you something:
favoriteExamples.original: Come on, Helen, you can tell me. I won't tell anyone.

favoriteExamples.definition: to continue doing something, or to cause something to continue:
favoriteExamples.original: Carry on the good work!

favoriteExamples.definition: to start doing a particular job or activity:
favoriteExamples.original: Patti took up (= continued) the story where Sue had left off.

favoriteExamples.definition: to wait for a short time:

favoriteExamples.definition: to wait for a short time:
favoriteExamples.original: Do you need the toilet right now or can you hang on for a while?

favoriteExamples.definition: to have a good relationship:
favoriteExamples.original: He doesn't get on with his daughter.

favoriteExamples.definition: to finally be in a particular place or situation:
favoriteExamples.original: After working her way around the world, she ended up teaching English as a foreign language.

favoriteExamples.definition: If you give up a habit, such as smoking, or something such as alcohol, you stop doing it or using it:
favoriteExamples.original: Don't offer him a cigarette, he's trying to give it up.

favoriteExamples.definition: to make a child stay inside as a punishment, or to make someone stay in hospital:

favoriteExamples.original: He's taken up the position of supervisor.

favoriteExamples.definition: to wait for a short time:

favoriteExamples.definition: to choose something:

favoriteExamples.definition: to raise something, or to fix something in a raised position:

favoriteExamples.definition: to take action in order to achieve something or in order to solve a problem:

favoriteExamples.definition: to destroy something or kill someone with a bomb, or to be destroyed or killed by a bomb:

favoriteExamples.definition: to remove something from somewhere:
favoriteExamples.original: They had to take out two of his teeth.

favoriteExamples.definition: to put an object that you are holding onto the floor or onto another surface, or to stop carrying someone:
favoriteExamples.original: Put me down, Daddy!

favoriteExamples.definition: If one thing goes with another, they suit each other or they look or taste good together:
favoriteExamples.original: I'm not sure that those shoes really go with that dress.

favoriteExamples.definition: to continue doing something, or to cause something to continue:
favoriteExamples.original: Sorry to interrupt, please carry on (with what you were saying).

favoriteExamples.definition: to wait or spend time somewhere, usually for no particular reason:
favoriteExamples.original: I thought I'd hang around for a while and see if she comes.

favoriteExamples.definition: to wait for a short time:
favoriteExamples.original: Hang on a minute - I'll be with you in a moment!

favoriteExamples.definition: to increase the price or value of something:
favoriteExamples.original: I see they've put up the price of fuel again.

favoriteExamples.definition: If you give up a habit, such as smoking, or something such as alcohol, you stop doing it or using it:
favoriteExamples.original: Don't offer him a cigarette, he's trying to give it up.

favoriteExamples.definition: to return something you have bought to a shop:
favoriteExamples.original: Is it too small? Take it back and get a refund.

favoriteExamples.definition: to return:
favoriteExamples.original: Let's go back to the beginning and start again.

favoriteExamples.definition: to fill something with air:
favoriteExamples.original: Would you help me blow up these balloons?

favoriteExamples.definition: to care for a child until they are an adult, often giving them particular beliefs:
favoriteExamples.original: They brought her up (as/to be) a Catholic.

favoriteExamples.definition: to stop doing a regular activity or job:
favoriteExamples.original: We're going to give up our sports club membership after this year.

favoriteExamples.definition: to arrange for someone or for yourself to stay at a hotel, etc.:
favoriteExamples.original: They've booked us into the hotel in the main square.

favoriteExamples.definition: to decide or arrange to delay an event or activity until a later time or date:
favoriteExamples.original: The meeting has been put off for a week.

favoriteExamples.definition: to hit someone with a vehicle and injure or kill them:
favoriteExamples.original: She was knocked down by a bus.

favoriteExamples.definition: to support a sports team or a sports player and want them to win:
favoriteExamples.original: Who do you root for in the Super Bowl?

favoriteExamples.definition: to subtract a number (= remove it from another number):
favoriteExamples.original: Four take away two is two.

favoriteExamples.definition: to try to find a piece of information by looking in a book or on a computer:
favoriteExamples.original: If you don't know what the word means, look it up in a dictionary.

favoriteExamples.definition: to end a phone conversation:
favoriteExamples.original: Let me speak to Melanie before you hang up.

favoriteExamples.definition: to raise something, or to fix something in a raised position:
favoriteExamples.original: I put my hand up to ask the teacher a question.

favoriteExamples.definition: to decide or arrange to delay an event or activity until a later time or date:
favoriteExamples.original: I can't put off going to the dentist any longer.

favoriteExamples.definition: to treat someone or something as if he, she, or it is not important or does not deserve serious attention:
favoriteExamples.original: If you say that, people will just laugh at you.

favoriteExamples.definition: to arrange for someone or for yourself to stay at a hotel, etc.:
favoriteExamples.original: I've booked you in at the Savoy.

favoriteExamples.definition: to give something to someone without asking for payment:
favoriteExamples.original: The shop is giving away a sample to every customer.

favoriteExamples.definition: to manage or deal with a situation, especially successfully:
favoriteExamples.original: We're getting on quite well with the decorating.

favoriteExamples.definition: to finally agree to what someone wants, after refusing for a period of time:
favoriteExamples.original: He nagged me so much for a new bike that eventually I gave in.

favoriteExamples.definition: If people or animals put weight on, they become heavier:
favoriteExamples.original: I'd expected to put weight on when I gave up smoking, but I didn't.

favoriteExamples.definition: said to encourage someone to do something, especially to hurry or try harder, or to tell you something:
favoriteExamples.original: Come on - we're going to be late if you don't hurry!

favoriteExamples.definition: When schools and colleges, or the teachers and students who go to them break up, their classes stop and the holidays start:
favoriteExamples.original: We broke up for the holidays in June.

favoriteExamples.definition: to use something so much that it is damaged and cannot be used any more, or to become damaged in this way:
favoriteExamples.original: Moving parts in engines wear out much more quickly than stationary parts.

favoriteExamples.definition: If one thing goes with another, they suit each other or they look or taste good together:
favoriteExamples.original: This wine goes particularly well with seafood.

favoriteExamples.definition: to visit a place and look at the things in it:
favoriteExamples.original: She spent the afternoon looking around the town.

favoriteExamples.definition: to make something continue at its present level and not allow it to fall:
favoriteExamples.original: You must eat to keep your strength up.

favoriteExamples.definition: to return something to the person who sent it to you, especially because it is damaged or not suitable:
favoriteExamples.original: I had to send the shirt back because it didn't fit me.

favoriteExamples.definition: to formally establish a new company, organization, system, way of working, etc.:
favoriteExamples.original: They've set up a fund for victims of the earthquake.

favoriteExamples.definition: to leave a closed vehicle, building, etc.:
favoriteExamples.original: I'll get out when you stop at the traffic lights.

favoriteExamples.definition: to continue without stopping or changing, or to continue something without allowing it to stop or change:
favoriteExamples.original: Keep up the good work!

favoriteExamples.definition: If you give up a habit, such as smoking, or something such as alcohol, you stop doing it or using it:
favoriteExamples.original: I gave up smoking two years ago.

favoriteExamples.definition: to be reduced in price, value, amount, quality, level, or size:
favoriteExamples.original: The company's shares went down 7p to 53p.

favoriteExamples.definition: to leave a place without taking someone or something with you:
favoriteExamples.original: He was forced to leave the country, leaving behind his wife and children.

favoriteExamples.definition: to wait for a short time:
favoriteExamples.original: Sally's on the other phone - would you like to hang on?

favoriteExamples.definition: to destroy something or kill someone with a bomb, or to be destroyed or killed by a bomb:
favoriteExamples.original: They threatened to blow up the plane if their demands were not met.

favoriteExamples.definition: to continue doing something, or to cause something to continue:
favoriteExamples.original: Daphne is carrying on the family tradition by becoming a lawyer.

favoriteExamples.definition: to stop doing a regular activity or job:
favoriteExamples.original: We're going to give up our sports club membership after this year.

favoriteExamples.definition: to make something such as a fire or cigarette stop burning:
favoriteExamples.original: Would you mind putting your cigarette out, please?

favoriteExamples.definition: to put something in the place or container where it is usually kept:
favoriteExamples.original: Put your toys away now.

favoriteExamples.definition: If you have clothes or shoes on, you are wearing them:
favoriteExamples.original: I loved that dress you had on last night.

favoriteExamples.definition: to write something on a piece of paper so that you do not forget it:
favoriteExamples.original: Did you write down Jo's phone number?

favoriteExamples.definition: to buy food in a restaurant and eat it somewhere else:
favoriteExamples.original: Is that to eat in or take out?

favoriteExamples.definition: to destroy something or kill someone with a bomb, or to be destroyed or killed by a bomb:
favoriteExamples.original: They threatened to blow up the plane if their demands were not met.

favoriteExamples.definition: to give someone something that another person has given you:
favoriteExamples.original: Could you pass it on to Laura when you've finished reading it?

favoriteExamples.definition: to get rid of something that you do not want any more:
favoriteExamples.original: So when are you going to throw away those old magazines?

favoriteExamples.definition: to stop doing a regular activity or job:
favoriteExamples.original: We're going to give up our sports club membership after this year.

favoriteExamples.definition: If you base something on facts or ideas, you use those facts or ideas to develop it:
favoriteExamples.original: The film is based on a short story by Thomas Mann.

favoriteExamples.definition: to move higher, rise, or increase:
favoriteExamples.original: The average cost of a new house has gone up by five percent to £276,500.

favoriteExamples.definition: to have a romantic and usually sexual relationship with someone:
favoriteExamples.original: How long have you been going out with him?

favoriteExamples.definition: to continue without stopping or changing, or to continue something without allowing it to stop or change:
favoriteExamples.original: Keep up the good work!

favoriteExamples.definition: to show your ticket at an airport so that you can be told where you will be sitting and so that your bags can be put on the aircraft:
favoriteExamples.original: You can save time by checking in online.

favoriteExamples.definition: to make something continue at its present level and not allow it to fall:
favoriteExamples.original: You must eat to keep your strength up.

favoriteExamples.definition: to be given something again that you had before:
favoriteExamples.original: Don't lend him money - you'll never get it back.

favoriteExamples.definition: to stop living in a particular home:
favoriteExamples.original: Her landlord has given her a week to move out.

favoriteExamples.definition: to continue doing something, or to cause something to continue:
favoriteExamples.original: Let's carry on this discussion at some other time.

favoriteExamples.definition: to fall to the ground:
favoriteExamples.original: Our apple tree fell down in the storm.

favoriteExamples.definition: to not go onto an area, or to stop someone or something going onto an area:
favoriteExamples.original: There was a notice saying 'Keep off the grass'.

favoriteExamples.definition: to protect someone or something and provide the things they need, especially someone who is young, old, or ill:
favoriteExamples.original: It's good to know that the dogs will be well cared for while we're away.

favoriteExamples.definition: to become involved in an activity with other people:
favoriteExamples.original: We only need one more player for this game - can you persuade your sister to join in?
